title: CMWSSB Labourers Union demand permanent jobs and better wages - The Hindu
text:
For years, several workers hired on contract have been waiting for permanent jobs and better wages at the Chennai Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (CMWSSB).
The CMWSSB Labourers‚Äô Union will hold a conference in the city to emphasise key demands. Nearly 2,850 labourers had been hired for sewer and water network maintenance, but most of them are without permanent jobs despite working for several years.
G. Beem Rao, former Maduravoyal MLA and the Union‚Äôs president, said though some of the basic demands, including safety gears and uniforms, have been met, the workers continue to struggle for secure jobs and better wages. ‚ÄúA separate category must be formed for skilled labourers with a hike in monthly salary fixed at a minimum of ‚Çπ26,000,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄôM.Palani, the Union‚Äôs general secretary, said labourers have been fighting for secure jobs and hike in wages for eight years now. ‚ÄúThe workers who have been engaged on contract for over three years must be provided permanent jobs. We staged several protests in the past. But promises are yet to be fulfilled,‚Äù he said.
A resolution would also be passed in support of the ongoing protest of Greater Chennai Corporation‚Äôs sanitation workers.

author: Elise Sol√© | TODAY
title: Should parents buy school supplies for the entire class? TikTok is divided
text:
‚ÄúCommunal‚Äù school supply lists are rattling parents on TikTok, with some asking, ‚ÄúWhy should I buy scissors and highlighters for other children?‚Äù
For many families, back-to-school shopping includes notebooks, markers and folders, not just for their kids but for their peers as well. While certain states require schools to provide basic supplies, classroom budgets are tight. To ensure that all children have enough supplies ‚Äî we‚Äôve seen how kids treat pencils, right? ‚Äî teachers often have two options: pay for a portion of supplies themselves, usually without reimbursement , or create ‚Äúwish lists‚Äù requesting families to contribute bulk items once or twice a year.
If you‚Äôre asked to buy two dozen glue sticks, it‚Äôs either because teachers expect your child to use every single one this year or they benefit students whose families can‚Äôt afford to buy supplies. Extras are also handy when items go missing or break. Teachers may ask parents to buy specific brands or basic, nondescript supplies without branding or flourishes. Sometimes teachers request bigger items, too, like whiteboard markers, disinfecting wipes and tissues.
Each teacher has their own system but most agree that no one wants to snatch Billy‚Äôs favorite Spider-Man eraser and give it to his mortal enemy. While specific guidelines vary by classroom, the purpose of general supplies is that they all look the same and are there for the taking as needed.
Some parents contribute, others cannot. And some have complicated feelings about the responsibility.
One mom on TikTok wrote, ‚ÄúI spent upwards of $400 on school stuff for seven kids a year. I am not buying for a whole class‚Äù while another simply said, ‚ÄúSome parents don‚Äôt like to share apparently.‚Äù
Frances Chie, a mom in Ohio, wants to buy personalized supplies for her 3-year-old daughter who is entering preschool this year, but not necessarily her peers. While their school only asks families to buy supplies for their own children, Chie suspects that communal supplies are in her future.
‚ÄúIf my baby wants Disney Princess pencils, a pencil case (and) erasers and I go and buy them, why wouldn‚Äôt she be using them?‚Äù Chie said in a TikTok video.
@lovefranceschiee What are your thoughts? ü§î | #schoolsupplies #backtoschool #momsoftiktok #greenscreen
‚ô¨ original sound ‚Äì Love Frances Chie üíï Parents and teachers responded:
‚ÄúI will label each crayon individually with my child‚Äôs name, a whole 128 pack. I don‚Äôt care.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat I buy for my children is THEIRS. And I will be telling their teachers the same.‚Äù ‚ÄúAs a teacher, I understand this but also, we have to pay for so much of it.‚Äù ‚ÄúFirst grade teacher here. The only supplies I use as community supplies are pencils and glue sticks, only because they need help managing supplies at this age. They will need 24 pencils, just not on Day One.‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think most parents understand how much little kids lose or break pencils and crayons.‚Äù ‚ÄúTeachers have to handle 18 to 25 children. Please just do whatever your teacher wants you to do.‚Äù Chie tells TODAY.com that she and her daughter are excited to find supplies branded with Disney, Bluey and unicorns.
‚ÄúIf parents are going school shopping with their little ones, and picking out things that (reflect) their special interests ‚Ä¶ those kids should use those supplies,‚Äù she says.
Chie says she was surprised to learn that many teachers pay for classroom decorations and supplies with their own money and she would be happy to donate more communal items, like paper towels, hand sanitizer and tissues to the classroom, but draws the line at more personal items.
Sarah Spikeston, a Texas mom and community college professor, is in favor of communal school supplies. (@sarahspikeston via TikTok) Sarah Spikeston of Texas pays a flat fee to her daughter‚Äôs private school to purchase communal supplies while her son‚Äôs private Montessori preschool allows for both personal and shared items.
‚ÄúAs someone who was chronically poor growing up and homeless for parts of (my youth), meeting the needs of all kids, regardless of their circumstances, is really important to me,‚Äù Spikeston, a community college professor in Texas, tells TODAY.com via email.
She adds: ‚ÄúI know what it‚Äôs like to be the kid that‚Äôs left without and that classrooms run more efficiently when they are fully stocked and there‚Äôs some level of uniformity in supplies.‚Äù
Spikeston says some parents dislike buying generic brands but kids don‚Äôt care about sharing supplies, especially when they‚Äôre expressing their individuality elsewhere.
‚ÄúWe have to remember that any of us could begin to struggle in the blink of an eye,‚Äù says Spikeston. ‚ÄúThose of us that are blessed to be able to afford school supplies have a duty to the community because the community in turn funds our public schools.‚Äù
Todd Bloch, a middle school science teacher in Michigan, understands that supplies are expensive and that families may have brand favorites or want to label their children‚Äôs supplies.
Supply lists are a ‚Äúbalancing act‚Äù for teachers, too.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to know exactly what we need going into the school year, especially when store sales usually happen in June,‚Äù Bloch tells TODAY.com.
When parents can afford to buy supplies, says Bloch, it saves teachers from diving into their classroom budgets so they can spend that money elsewhere ‚Äî like baking soda and vinegar to demonstrate chemical reactions with a ‚Äúcool‚Äù fizz, he says.
With experience, Bloch has fine-tuned his supply list: kids trace perfect circles using cheap paper coffee cups instead of compasses, technological information can be stored in the cloud versus flash drives, and standard pencils trump refillable mechanical tools. When Bloch‚Äôs students built solar ovens with aluminum foil and cardboard, they brought in their family‚Äôs used pizza boxes. It helps that Bloch‚Äôs school reimburses him a portion of what he spends. If Bloch wants to do something special, like reward his students with Jolly Ranchers, he pays out of his own pocket.
Bloch communicates his recommendations for supplies to parents and reassures students they will be fully prepared, one way or another.
‚ÄúTeachers just want to create an equitable experience for students,‚Äù says Bloch. ‚ÄúIf parents can‚Äôt help make that happen, most teachers totally understand.‚Äù

title: La playa fluvial m√°s espectacular de Segovia: ocio, relax y diversi√≥n en un impresionante paraje natural del Durat√≥n
text:
La ola de calor que est√° a punto de llegar a Espa√±a, incluido a Castilla y Le√≥n, hace que los √∫nicos planes que apetezcan sean aquellos en los que el agua es el principal protagonista.
En estas fechas en las que el calor aprieta y con fuerza, hay quienes optan por la playa. Otros se decantan por la piscina y luego est√°n los que, por unos motivos u otros, eligen parajes naturales √∫nicos y excepcionales que te har√°n sentir como si estuvieras en una zona de costa, pero con unas vistas a√∫n m√°s impresionantes.
Uno de estos entornos se halla en la provincia de Segovia, concretamente, entre las localidades de San Miguel de Bernuy y Fuentidue√±a, en el paraje La Serranilla.
All√≠ se ubica el embalse de Las Venc√≠as, tambi√©n conocido como playa de Las Venc√≠as, un lugar rodeado de naturaleza y ubicado en la ribera del r√≠o Durat√≥n, en el que es posible, relajarse, disfrutar y desconectar al mismo tiempo.
Y es que, a dicho embalse se trasladan cada fin de semana y durante la temporada estival, cientos de familias y grupos de amigos para realizar actividades acu√°ticas, refrescarse, tomar el sol y hasta para divertirse en alguno de sus chiringuitos, siendo el Lago Bar La Serranilla uno de los m√°s conocidos.
Imagen de la playa de Las Venc√≠as y la terraza de uno de sus chiringuitos Lago Bar La Serranilla
En √©l suelen celebrarse todo tipo de fiestas, actuaciones en directo y, adem√°s, se pueden alquilar kayaks, piraguas, canoas, tablas de p√°del surf y hasta hidropedales. Del mismo modo, cuenta con todo tipo de bebidas y servicio de comidas, para que todos los interesados puedan disfrutar de una estupenda y deliciosa experiencia culinaria a orillas del Durat√≥n. All√≠ se puede comprar un bocadillo, como encargar las mejores paellas.
Las Venc√≠as, un embalse que, aunque fue construido con fines hidroel√©ctricos, hoy funciona como zona de ocio, tambi√©n cuenta con hamacas y sombrillas, un agua limpia y cristalina y, como no pod√≠a ser de otra manera, con una amplia y extensa zona de arena fina. Tanto, que a pesar de que no es poca la gente que frecuenta el pantano, casi nunca se ve masificado.
All√≠ tambi√©n se pueden observar infinidad de buitres que sobrevuelan la zona y una vegetaci√≥n de ribera que hacen de este espacio un entorno √∫nico y excepcional, as√≠ como todo un reclamo tur√≠stico, ya no solo para los segovianos que se pasan por all√≠ cada fin de semana de verano, sino tambi√©n para madrile√±os y castellanos y leoneses que, por lo general, se muestran encantados con este plan. Adem√°s, cabe destacar que es un lugar ideal para pescar.
A todo ello se suma que aquellos que deciden recorrer el embalse, ya sea en canoa, kayak, piragua o hidropedal, pueden contemplar un sinf√≠n de atractivos naturales y arquitect√≥nicos, muchos de ellos acu√°ticos, que van desde meandros hasta acantilados e incluso ruinas rom√°nicas.
En definitiva, un maravilloso paraje donde todo, o casi todo, es posible. Es como ir a la playa sin tener que realizar un desplazamiento largo y encima en un lugar con un paisaje de postal. ¬øTe lo vas a perder?

El grupo musical La Bella Luz enfrenta una serie de salidas de sus integrantes, desde marzo de 2024 hasta febrero de este 2025. La situaci√≥n ha generado preocupaci√≥n entre los fan√°ticos, debido a que varios artistas explicaron que decidieron irse para priorizar su bienestar emocional.

En aquel entonces, celebr√≥ la incorporaci√≥n de las voces de Naldy Salda√±a, Alejandra Guerrero, Deyvis Paredes, Hanna Delgado, Kevin C√©spedes y Eduardo Ort√∫zar. Incluso, Briela Cirilo iba a ser la s√©ptima integrante, pero termin√≥ volviendo a Coraz√≥n Serrano por una mejor oferta econ√≥mica.
Semanas m√°s tarde, el grupo se fortaleci√≥ con la llegada de Claudia Salazar, Alexandra Seijas y Math√≠as Zevallos, quienes resultaron ganadores del casting que se realiz√≥ en el programa ‚ÄòMande quien mande‚Äô, cuya final fue el 19 de marzo de 2024. El segundo cantante de La Bella Luz en irse en el 2024 fue Kevin Cespedes, quien hizo p√∫blica su salida a trav√©s de un comunicado de prensa. Aunque ni la orquesta ni el cantante revelaron el verdadero motivo de su salida de La Bella Luz, algunos expertos en cumbia aseguraron que el int√©rprete estaba inc√≥modo porque no le daban temas a grabar, tal y como s√≠ pas√≥ con los ganadores del casting.
Ale Seijas dej√≥ La Bella Luz por ‚Äúmotivos forzados‚Äù
El 7 de agosto de 2024, la cantante Alexandra Seijas sorprendi√≥ a sus miles de fan√°ticos al compartir un comunicado sobre su salida de la orquesta. ‚ÄúAnuncio que dejo de pertenecer a La Bella Luz, dejando en claro mi renuncia, por motivos forzados. Muchas gracias a todo el p√∫blico que siempre me ha apoyado en todo momento. Y espero seguir contando con el apoyo de todos ustedes‚Äù, indic√≥.
El comunicado de Ale Seijas dispar√≥ las alarmas de que algo estaba sucediendo en la agrupaci√≥n, pero nadie aclar√≥ nada. Despu√©s de su renuncia, la joven intent√≥ hacer una carrera como solista. Incluso, expres√≥ sus deseos de formar parte de Coraz√≥n Serrano, pero Edwin Guerro dijo que no contratar√° a nadie que haya estado en La Bella Luz para evitar problemas con la competencia. Finalmente, la joven fue fichada por Son del Duke, tras la salida de Cielo Fern√°ndez, la √∫ltima contrataci√≥n de Coraz√≥n Serrano.
Claudia Salazar se fue de La Bella Luz por su paz mental
Claudia Salazar, reconocida por su dedicaci√≥n y entusiasmo en La Bella Luz, anunci√≥ su salida de La Bella Luz el 1 de enero de este 2025, a trav√©s de un comunicado, donde explic√≥ que esta decisi√≥n responde a la necesidad de priorizar su tranquilidad. ‚ÄúHe decidido dejar este proyecto musical, una decisi√≥n dif√≠cil, pero necesaria para priorizar mi bienestar y paz mental‚Äù, indic√≥ en su mensaje compartido en Instagram.
Adem√°s, la cantante expres√≥ su agradecimiento a sus seguidores, quienes han sido un pilar fundamental en su carrera, brind√°ndole inspiraci√≥n constante a trav√©s de sus mensajes y aplausos. ‚ÄúAgradezco profundamente a todos mis fans por su apoyo, que ha sido una fuente infinita de inspiraci√≥n. A pesar de que cierro este cap√≠tulo, espero seguir contando con su compa√±√≠a en los nuevos caminos musicales que me esperan‚Äù, concluy√≥ Salazar, quien en la actualidad se desempe√±a como cantante de Papill√≥n.
Mathias Zevallos, la joven promesa de la cumbia, se fue de La Bella Luz
Cuando todo parec√≠a que se hab√≠a calmado en la interna de La Bella Luz, incluso se hab√≠an reforzado con el ingreso de Stiven Franco, el cantante Mathias Zevallos sorprendi√≥ a m√°s de uno al anunciar su retiro de La Bella Luz, a pesar de que se hab√≠a convertido en una de las principales voces de la orquesta.
‚ÄúQuiero hacer p√∫blico mi retiro de la orquesta La Bella Luz. Agradezco al Sr. Oscar Custodio por la oportunidad brindada, ya que formar parte de la agrupaci√≥n ha sido una experiencia que ha contribuido significativamente a mi crecimiento art√≠stico. Asimismo, quiero expresar mi m√°s profundo cari√±o a mis fans que han seguido mi trayectoria y han apoyado mi carrera musical‚Äù, expres√≥ en sus redes.
Eduardo Ort√∫zar fue el √∫ltimo en irse de La Bella Luz
Un d√≠a despu√©s del comunicado de Math√≠as Zevallos, el cantante Eduardo Ort√∫zar tambi√©n anunci√≥ su renuncia a La Bella Luz. El int√©rprete de cumbia indic√≥ que fue su decisi√≥n salir de la delantera del grupo, con el fin de ‚Äúpriorizar mi estabilidad emocional‚Äù. Asimismo, agradeci√≥ al se√±or Oscar Custodio por la oportunidad y sostuvo que est√° abierto a nuevas oportunidades de trabajo.

author: Ethan James
title: Yacht damage, broken bones in squally Sydney to Hobart
text:
Uncomfortable weather is showing no sign of letting up for a Sydney to Hobart fleet already battered by squally conditions that have damaged yachts and broken ribs.
More than 70 boats remained at sea late on Friday afternoon, with the day's first finisher not arriving until 1pm (AEDT) - some 29 hours after LawConnect claimed line honours victory.
Tasmanian yacht Alive, which finished on Thursday, is primed to take out overall honours for a second occasion with a time that appears unbeatable.
Official confirmation is likely to occur on Saturday.
No Limit and 12-year-old luxury cruiser Whisper were among a handful of yachts to make it to the safety of Hobart's Constitution Dock on Friday afternoon.
"Tough ... wet, lumpy, plenty of wind. But the team did an amazing job," No Limit skipper David Gotze said after his seventh-place finish across the line.
"We did the best with what we could do in the circumstances."
The retirement tally stands at 16 from 103 starters following a stormy Boxing Day night at sea.
A strong wind warning is in place for waters off Tasmania's east coast, where a chunk of the fleet is tracking south.
Cruising Yacht Club of Australia commodore Arthur Lane said winds of 35 knots and 4.5-metre seas were expected on Friday afternoon and night.
"It is certainly slower than the last few years and that is because of the wind. It is an uphill race," he told AAP.
"It's going to be a very uncomfortable night."
NSW entrant Salt Lines, veteran of 22 Sydney to Hobart races, and 52-footer Gunshot pulled the pin on Thursday night because of damage to their sails.
Robbie Fisher, skipper of 66-footer Helsal 3, reported a broken mainsail rope, torn sail and "other little things".
"We have a minor injury to a crew ... our navigator was on deck, slipped, and cracked a couple of ribs," he said.
"We copped a beating across (Bass) Strait. We had over 30 knots and it was pretty bad. We have persevered though."
Hong Kong entrant Antipodes, crewed by Lindsay May in his 50th race, was slated to finish at some point on Friday.
"We've had some down time ... with breeze holes that our competitors didn't get," crew member Brad Kellett said.
"We've got a tear in the new mainsail to repair. We blew out our J2 headsail."
The Darren Hine-skippered Alive, overall winner in 2018, finished as clubhouse leader on handicap time.
The overall winner, which is awarded the Tattersall Cup, is judged on handicap which takes into account factors including the size of the boat.
LawConnect won line honours on Thursday morning, coming from behind to beat fellow 100-footer and 2022 winner Andoo Comanche by just 51 seconds in the second-closest finish in Sydney to Hobart history.

title: Sharp rise in religious hate crimes recorded by UK‚Äôs largest police forces | East Anglian Daily Times
text: The number of antisemitic hate crimes recorded by many of the UK‚Äôs largest police forces jumped sharply in the weeks following the outbreak of the Hamas-Israel conflict, new figures reveal. Islamophobic offences also rose for some forces, although the picture was more mixed across the country. Jewish charities called the findings ‚Äúshocking‚Äù, while campaigners against anti-Muslim abuse said the data was ‚Äúdeeply worrying‚Äù. The Home Office condemned the rise in offences, adding: ‚ÄúThere is no place for hate in our society.‚Äù The figures have been obtained by the PA news agency using Freedom of Information requests. They show that: ‚Äì Greater Manchester Police recorded 74 antisemitic offences in the month following the Hamas attacks on Israel on October 7, compared with 15 for the same period in 2022 and 14 in 2021, while West Yorkshire Police recorded 53, compared with 10 (2022) and 14 (2021). ‚Äì West Midlands Police recorded 22 antisemitic offences from October 7 to November 7, compared with one (2022) and eight (2021), while Merseyside Police recorded 20 compared with four (both 2022 and 2021). ‚Äì The British Transport Police had one of the largest increases, recording 87 antisemitic offences in the month after October 7, up from eight in the same period in 2022 and 11 in 2021, as well as a jump in Islamophobic offences with 22 (2023), up from two (2022) and eight (2021). ‚Äì West Yorkshire recorded 49 Islamophobic offences in this period in 2023, up from 29 (2022) and 38 (2021), but the pattern was not so clear for Greater Manchester (34 in 2023, 43 in 2022 and 42 in 2021) or West Midlands (25 in 2023, 33 in 2022 and 23 in 2021). The Community Security Trust described the figures as ‚Äúshocking‚Äù and said they made clear ‚Äúthe extent of the unacceptable rise in anti-Jewish hatred across the country since the Hamas terror attack on October 7‚Äù. A spokesman for the Jewish charity said: ‚ÄúThis wave of antisemitism was triggered by the mass murder, rape and kidnapping of Jews in Israel, and is fuelled and sustained by extremist hatred online and on our streets. ‚ÄúIt is essential that perpetrators are identified and prosecuted, and that wider society shows its disgust for this racist hate crime.‚Äù Tell Mama, which monitors and works to tackle anti-Muslim sentiment and abuse in the UK, told PA that ‚Äúlevels of anti-Muslim hatred and discrimination are deeply worrying, impacting trust in authorities and their sense of identity and belonging‚Äù. Iman Atta, the organisation‚Äôs director, said there had been a ‚Äúsignificant spike in anti-Muslim hate since the atrocities on October 7‚Äù, adding: ‚ÄúThe nature of many offline cases sent to our service is often overtly racist ‚Äì targeting Arab and Palestinian communities with dehumanising slurs, anti-Muslim slurs or in some cases targeting their homes, or when speaking Arabic in public, as well as targeting Muslim communities across all ages and gender. ‚ÄúWe should never allow such hatred and intolerance to take root in our communities and at this time, please look out for each other, whether Muslim or Jewish. We must stand together against intolerance, hate and racism.‚Äù The Metropolitan Police, the largest force in the UK, said delays prevented it from supplying full figures until the new year, but it had previously reported 218 antisemitic and 101 Islamophobic offences between October 1 and 18 this year, compared with 15 and 42 respectively in the same period in 2022. PA obtained full responses from 31 of the 46 forces across the UK, with the data representing a snapshot of what has currently been recorded by forces and is therefore subject to change. Methods for recording hate crime are not consistent across forces, so the data cannot be used to compare the number of offences between different areas or provide an overall total for the whole of the UK. But the figures do point to a jump in antisemitic offences recorded by forces concentrated mostly in cities or across built-up areas, while the pattern for Islamophobic offences was more varied. Some forces that operate across a mix of urban and less populated areas tend to show a similar pattern, although with lower volumes of offences ‚Äì for example Hertfordshire Police (17 antisemitic offences for the period in 2023, compared with six in 2022 and three in 2021) and Thames Valley Police (21 antisemitic offences in 2023, one in 2022 and four in 2021). Data obtained from smaller forces, or those covering areas with few towns or cities, typically showed low numbers of offences, often in single figures, meaning a clear trend was hard to determine. A spokesman for the Board of Deputies of British Jews said the findings ‚Äúprovide further evidence of the huge upsurge in antisemitism following the Hamas massacre of October 7‚Äù. The board, seen as the voice of the British Jewish community with over 300 deputies directly elected by the synagogues and communal organisations they represent, told PA the rise in antisemitism had ‚Äúcaused enormous anxiety for Jewish people, particularly children and Jewish students on campus or indeed anyone easily identified as Jewish by their dress‚Äù. A spokesman added: ‚ÄúWe call on police to take strong action against anyone found to be perpetrating hate crimes.‚Äù The Muslim Council of Britain said: ‚ÄúDespite the extremely low reporting rate from Muslim communities, the huge increase in Islamophobic hate crimes recorded with the police reflects what we are seeing from third-party reporting groups. ‚ÄúThe Government‚Äôs laissez-faire attitude to Islamophobia contrasts strongly with its no-tolerance approach to antisemitism. We are hopeful this will now change.‚Äù A spokesperson for the Home Office said: ‚ÄúThere is no place for hate in our society and we condemn the recent rise in reported antisemitic and anti-Muslim hatred. ‚ÄúWe expect the police to fully investigate all hate crimes and work with the CPS to make sure the cowards who commit these abhorrent offences feel the full force of the law. ‚ÄúFollowing recent events, we have also made further funding available to Jewish and Muslim communities, to provide additional security at places of worship and faith schools.‚Äù
